awd_titl_txt: TRAVEL PROPOSAL: STUDENT PROGRAM OF THE FIFTH CONFERENCE ON AI, ETHICS AND SOCIETY (AIES 2022)
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports to student travel for select students participating in the student program at the 5th Conference on AI, Ethics, and Society (AIES) that will be held in August, 2022 in Oxford, UK.  AIES is an up and coming international conference for researchers that investigate that impact that artificial intelligence has at various levels of society. This activity will bring together a broad community of researchers in this important field and supports junior researchers at this critical early-career stage.  The student program creates the opportunity to bring in participants who might not have attended an AI conference due to lack of resources. This is especially true for those at smaller institutions and those which have less developed AI programs. Engaging such participants has the potential to draw more talent into AI research, improve research ideas in their formative stage, and engender collaborations across the breadth of disciplines.  This event provides students with invaluable exposure to outside perspectives on their work at a critical time in their research and enables them to explore their career objectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This NSF travel grant supported the participation of a select group of U.S.-based Ph.D. students in the student programs of the Fifth and Sixth AAAI/ACM Conference on AI, Ethics, and Society (AIES 2022 and AIES 2023), held in Oxford, UK (August 1-2, 2022), and Montreal, Canada (August 8-10, 2023), respectively. As artificial intelligence increasingly shapes fundamental aspects of human life, it is crucial to consider AI's present and future responsibly, necessitating dialogue not only among technologists but also with experts across the humanities and social sciences. AIES was founded seven years ago to fulfill this need, and its inaugural meeting in February 2018 in New Orleans, LA, was a success. A key part of the conference is the student track, which provides students with a gateway into the conference. Similar to previous editions, the student tracks of the last two years offered structured opportunities for students to engage with the interdisciplinary group of scholars attending AIES.

The AIES 2022 student program was highly successful, with 86 submissions from students across 8 different countries. Each submission received two reviews from members of the program committee, and 41 were accepted. Two U.S. citizens or permanent residents were supported by this grant. In 2023, the student program received 93 submissions from 10 different countries, with 38 accepted. Accepted students received free registration and a travel grant, with eleven U.S. citizens or permanent residents supported by this grant. During both doctoral programs, accepted students presented posters, met senior members of the community and company representatives, participated in a student lunch, and published a two-page extended abstract of their work in the proceedings.

 

Intellectual Merit: AIES has established itself as a valuable platform for students from diverse disciplines to learn from AI experts across fields, including not only computer science but also sociology, philosophy, economics, and law. This exposure enriched students' understanding of both the opportunities and risks associated with their work. The student tracks also served as an important cohort-building opportunity. In addition to computer science students, a small group of highly engaged students from the humanities and social sciences participated in both editions, contributing diverse perspectives to the discussion. The AIES 2022 and 2023 student programs provided these students with opportunities to connect with one another and the broader conference, fostering potential collaborative research and individual research endeavors enriched by interdisciplinary interactions at AIES.

Broader Impact: Interdisciplinary research on AI is crucial to ensure that technologies are developed and used to promote individual and social well-being, while alleviating rather than exacerbating structural injustices. Conferences like AIES provide essential forums for interdisciplinary analysis and foster collaboration between technologists and scholars from fields such as sociology, philosophy, political science, and law. While these interdisciplinary spaces are valuable for current professionals, they are especially impactful for students, who are still exploring what is expected of them as future professionals in the field. AIES serves as a model for aspiring scholars by exposing them to current work across a variety of disciplines and illustrating what meaningful interdisciplinary scholarship can achieve. By engaging with leading experts across complementary disciplines, the conference contributed to the development of student cohorts that will play a crucial role in the international research community. The topics addressed at AIES 2022 and 2023 will equip these students to advance science and high-tech industries in the U.S. while remaining conscious of critical issues such as user privacy, algorithmic bias, and the role of technology in shaping society. Furthermore, the programs attracted a diverse group of participants in terms of discipline, gender, ethnicity, and academic background, contributing to a more inclusive AI research community.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2024
Modified by: Kristen B Venable
